title: Amoxicillin Oral: Uses, Side Effects, Interactions, Pictures, Warnings & Dosing - WebMD
description: Find patient medical information for amoxicillin oral on WebMD including its uses, side effects and safety, interactions, pictures, warnings and user ratings.
cleaned_text: Uses Amoxicillin is used to treat a wide variety of [bacterial infections](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/bacterial-and-viral-infections). This [medication](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx) is a [penicillin](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/2/drug-3781/penicillin+g+benzathine+intramuscular/details)-type antibiotic. It works by stopping the growth of bacteria.This antibiotic treats only bacterial infections. It will not work for [viral infections](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/bacterial-and-viral-infections) (such as [common cold](https://www.webmd.com/cold-and-flu/cold-or-flu-quiz), [flu](https://www.webmd.com/cold-and-flu/cold-or-flu-quiz)). Using any antibiotic when it is not needed can cause it to not work for future infections.Amoxicillin is also used with other [medications](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx) to treat [stomach](https://www.webmd.com/digestive-disorders/picture-of-the-stomach)/intestinal ulcers caused by the bacteria H. pylori and to prevent the ulcers from returning. How to use amoxicillin oral Take this [medication](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx) by [mouth](https://www.webmd.com/oral-health/anatomy-of-the-mouth) with or without food as directed by your doctor, usually every 8 or 12 hours. The dosage is based on your medical condition and response to treatment. Drink plenty of fluids while using this medication unless your doctor tells you otherwise. For the best effect, take this antibiotic at evenly spaced times. To help you remember, take this medication at the same time(s) every day. Continue to take this medication until the full prescribed amount is finished, even if symptoms disappear after a few days. Stopping the medication too early may allow bacteria to continue to grow, which may result in a return of the infection. Tell your doctor if your condition lasts or gets worse. Side Effects [Nausea](https://www.webmd.com/digestive-disorders/digestive-diseases-nausea-vomiting), [vomiting](https://www.webmd.com/digestive-disorders/digestive-diseases-nausea-vomiting), or [diarrhea](https://www.webmd.com/digestive-disorders/digestive-diseases-diarrhea) may occur. If any of these effects last or get worse, tell your doctor or [pharmacist](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/features/pharmacists-they-do-more-than-fill-prescriptions) promptly. Remember that this [medication](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx) has been prescribed because your doctor has judged that the benefit to you is greater than the risk of side effects. Many people using this medication do not have serious side effects. Use of this medication for prolonged or repeated periods may result in oral [thrush](https://www.webmd.com/oral-health/what-is-thrush) or a new [vaginal yeast infection](https://www.webmd.com/women/understanding-vaginal-yeast-infection-basics) (oral or vaginal [fungal infection](https://www.webmd.com/skin-problems-and-treatments/fungal-infections-skin)). Contact your doctor if you notice white patches in your [mouth](https://www.webmd.com/oral-health/anatomy-of-the-mouth), a change in [vaginal discharge](https://www.webmd.com/women/vaginal-discharge-whats-abnormal) or other new symptoms. Tell your doctor right away if you have any serious side effects, including: signs of [liver disease](https://www.webmd.com/hepatitis/liver-and-hepatic-diseases) (such as nausea/vomiting [dark urine](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/brown-urine-causes)), easy bruising or bleeding. This medication may rarely cause a severe intestinal condition due to a bacteria called C. difficile. This condition may occur during treatment or weeks to months after treatment has stopped. Tell your doctor right away if you develop: [diarrhea](https://www.webmd.com/digestive-disorders/diarrhea-10/slideshow-foods-to-avoid) that doesn't stop, abdominal or [stomach pain](https://www.webmd.com/pain-management/abdominal-pain-causes-treatments)/cramping, [blood](https://www.webmd.com/heart/anatomy-picture-of-blood)/ [mucus](https://www.webmd.com/allergies/features/the-truth-about-mucus) in your stool. If you have these symptoms, do not use anti- [diarrhea](https://www.webmd.com/video/drossman-diarrhea-overview) or [opioid](https://www.webmd.com/pain-management/narcotic-pain-medications) products because they may make symptoms worse. A very serious [allergic reaction](https://www.webmd.com/allergies/allergic-reaction-causes) to this drug is rare. However, get medical help right away if you notice any symptoms of a serious [allergic reaction](https://www.webmd.com/allergies/anaphylaxis-15/slideshow-allergy-triggers), including: fever that doesn't go away, new or node swelling](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/tc/swollen-lymph-nodes-topic-overview), Amoxicillin can commonly cause a mild [rash](https://www.webmd.com/children/environmental-exposure-head2toe/slideshow-skin-irritants) that is usually not serious. However, you may not be able to tell it apart from a rare rash that could be a sign of a [severe allergic reaction](https://www.webmd.com/allergies/allergic-symptoms). Get medical help right away if you develop any rash. This is not a complete list of possible side effects. If you notice other effects not listed above, contact your doctor or pharmacist. In the US - Call your doctor for medical advice about side effects. You may report side effects to FDA at 1-800-FDA-1088 or at www.fda.gov/medwatch. In Canada - Call your doctor for medical advice about side effects. You may report side effects to Health Canada at 1-866-234-2345. Precautions Before taking amoxicillin, tell your doctor or [pharmacist](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/features/pharmacists-they-do-more-than-fill-prescriptions) if you are allergic to it; or to [penicillin](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/2/drug-3781/penicillin+g+benzathine+intramuscular/details) or cephalosporin [antibiotics](https://www.webmd.com/cold-and-flu/rm-quiz-antibiotics-myths-facts); or if you have any other [allergies](https://www.webmd.com/allergies/allergy-relief-10/slideshow-allergy-myths-facts). This product may contain inactive ingredients, which can cause allergic reactions or other problems. Talk to your pharmacist for more details. Before using this [medication](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx), tell your doctor or pharmacist your medical history, especially of: [kidney (such as [typhoid](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/typhoid) [vaccine](https://www.webmd.com/children/vaccines/immunizations-vaccines-power-of-preparation)) to not work well. Tell your [health care](https://www.webmd.com/health-insurance/rm-quiz-insurance-basics) professional that you are using amoxicillin before having any [immunizations](https://www.webmd.com/children/vaccines/immunizations-vaccines-power-of-preparation)/ [vaccinations](https://www.webmd.com/children/vaccines/immunizations-vaccines-power-of-preparation). Before having surgery, tell your doctor or [dentist](https://www.webmd.com/oral-health/oral-health-care-providers) about all the products you use (including [prescription drugs](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx), nonprescription drugs, and herbal products). During pregnancy, this medication should be used only when clearly needed. Discuss the risks and benefits with your doctor. Amoxicillin passes into [breast](https://www.webmd.com/women/picture-of-the-breasts) milk. Consult your doctor before breast-feeding. Interactions [Drug interactions](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/video/vd-0801-atsp-12) may change how your [medications](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx) work or increase your risk for serious side effects. This document does not contain all possible drug interactions. Keep a list of all the products you use (including prescription/nonprescription drugs and herbal products) and share it with your doctor and [pharmacist](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/features/pharmacists-they-do-more-than-fill-prescriptions). Do not start, stop, or change the dosage of any medicines without your doctor's approval. A product that may interact with this drug is: [methotrexate](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/2/drug-3441/methotrexate+(anti-rheumatic)+oral/details). This [medication](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx) may interfere with certain lab tests (such as certain diabetic urine tests), possibly causing false test results. Make sure lab personnel and all your doctors know you use this drug. Overdose If someone has overdosed and has serious symptoms such as passing out or [trouble breathing](https://www.webmd.com/lung/breathing-problems-causes-tests-treatments), call 911. Otherwise, call a poison control center right away. US residents can call their local poison control center at 1-800-222-1222. Canada residents can call a provincial poison control center. Symptoms of [overdose](https://www.webmd.com/mental-health/addiction/drug-overdose) may include: [diarrhea](https://www.webmd.com/digestive-disorders/digestive-diseases-diarrhea) that doesn't stop, severe [vomiting](https://www.webmd.com/digestive-disorders/digestive-diseases-nausea-vomiting), a severe decrease in the amount of urine, or [seizures](https://www.webmd.com/epilepsy/understanding-seizures-basics). Do not share this [medication](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx) with others. This medication has been prescribed for your current condition only. Do not use it later for another infection unless your doctor tells you to. With prolonged treatment, lab and/or medical tests (such as [kidney](https://www.webmd.com/kidney-stones/picture-of-the-kidneys)/ [liver function](https://www.webmd.com/hepatitis/liver-function-test-lft), complete [blood](https://www.webmd.com/heart/anatomy-picture-of-blood) counts) may be done while you are taking this medication. Keep all medical and lab appointments. Consult your doctor for more details. If you miss a dose, use it as soon as you remember. If it is near the time of the next dose, skip the missed dose. Use your next dose at the regular time. Do not double the dose to catch up. Store at room temperature away from light and moisture. Do not store in the bathroom. Keep all [medications](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx) away from children and pets. Do not flush medications down the toilet or pour them into a drain unless instructed to do so. Properly discard this product when it is expired or no longer needed. Consult your [pharmacist](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/features/pharmacists-they-do-more-than-fill-prescriptions) or local waste disposal company.
